title: Serious Question: Does Air-Drying Your Hair Encourage Mold?
description: .disclaimer{width:90%;margin-bottom:1rem}.disclaimer__lines{width:100%;margin:0 auto;border-bottom:1px solid #999;padding:0;max-width:150px}.disclaimer__copy{width:100%;max-width:355px;font-family:Brown Regular,sans-serif;font-size:.9rem;font-weight:300;line-height:1.3em;color:#333;padding:0 0 .4rem;margin:1rem auto;text-align:center} All linked products are independently selected by our editors. If you purchase any of these products, we may earn a commission. Mold makes an appearance in beauty products more often than we like to admit, whether it‚Äôs a brand that has formulated its moisturizer without preservatives (they‚Äôre essential for keeping bacteria at bay) or storing your makeup in a hot and steamy bathroom (the optimum environment for microorganisms to thrive in). And while mold can turn up pretty much anywhere, you‚Äôd assume that your skin is safe. But that hasn‚Äôt stopped TikTok from falling down something of a rabbit hole lately. Whether you‚Äôre a chronic scroller or open the app every once in a while, you might‚Äôve seen this viral video posted by content creator Kaley aka @allthingskaley. An enormous 18.2 million people already have, and the phrase ‚Äúhair mold‚Äù is trending as a result. In the clip, Kaley says that she blow-dries her hair as soon as she gets out of the shower so that she ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt get mold‚Äù. At first it caused confusion but then came a handful of comments from people who do the very same. The common school of thought? That air-drying your hair ‚Äî or going to sleep with wet hair ‚Äî can encourage mold to grow on your scalp.¬† @allthingskaley Have you heard of hair mold? I‚Äôm actually terrified now üò≥ #hairmold #preventhairmold #howtopreventhairmold #whatishairmold ‚ô¨ Funny video ‚ÄúCarmen Prelude‚Äù Arranging weakness(836530) ‚Äì yo suzuki(akisai) As expected, TikTok began to panic. ‚ÄúWhat does hair mold look like????‚Äù asked one commenter. Another wrote, ‚ÄúI have never heard of hair mold until now‚Ä¶I‚Äôm also terrified!!!‚Äù Can mold grow in your hair and on your scalp?¬† In my 10 years of beauty experience, I‚Äôve never come across hair mold. So is it really a thing? And should you be worried? I put the question to a trichologist and a dermatologist with a specialism in hair.¬† First of all, it pays to understand what mold actually is. Molds are fungi, which feed off moisture. They can be harmful, and people with health issues may be sensitive to certain types. In moist environments, mold can technically grow anywhere, but is air-drying ‚Äî or sleeping with wet hair ‚Äî likely to cause it on your scalp or in your hair strands?¬† ‚ÄúIn short, no,‚Äù says Dr. Sharon Wong, consultant dermatologist and British Skin Foundation spokesperson. ‚ÄúMold that you find in the air or on damp walls and surfaces is caused by a variety of different fungal species, and they are not the same as the yeasts that live naturally on human scalps,‚Äù she says.¬† What is malassezia ‚Äî and how does it affect the scalp? Before we get into the nitty gritty, it‚Äôs important to note that said yeasts are totally normal. A common yeast that lives on our scalp is called malassezia, explains trichologist Eva Proudman FIT IAT. It‚Äôs different from mold but, says Dr. Wong, ‚ÄúThe combination of damp hair together with the heat emitted from the scalp surface creates the perfect warm, moist environment that encourages overgrowth of malassezia.‚Äù Proudman explains that when the malassezia yeast becomes overactive (usually the result of excess oil on the scalp), it can lead to dandruff and seborrhoeic dermatitis, a type of scalp eczema. So what‚Äôs the difference? ‚ÄúDandruff causes loose white flakes that fall easily onto the shoulders, and in many cases does not itch,‚Äù says Proudman. ‚ÄúSeborrhoeic dermatitis causes the flakes to turn yellow as they feed off of oil, and for them to sit on the scalp and within the hair,‚Äù she continues. ‚ÄúSeborrhoeic dermatitis is also usually itchy and causes inflammation on the scalp.‚Äù¬† While there is no ‚Äúcure‚Äù for dandruff, washing your hair more frequently ‚Äî and starting off with an anti-dandruff shampoo like Nizoral Anti-Dandruff Daily Prevent Shampoo, $15.88, or Verb Dandruff Shampoo with Salicylic Acid for Dry and Flaky Scalp, $20 ‚Äî can help. Regularly washing your hair is also recommended to treat seborrhoeic dermatitis, as it thrives in oily environments.¬†¬†¬† Can mold grow on your pillow? While it‚Äôs very unlikely that mold can grow on your hair and scalp, your pillows and pillowcases are not exempt, says Proudman. ‚Äú[These] will absorb moisture and become damp from wet hair, which can lead to the fabrics becoming smelly and developing mold,‚Äù she says. If you do sleep with wet hair, Proudman recommends changing your pillowcase daily and ensuring that the pillow is always dry. If you head to bed with dry hair, Dr. Wong suggests changing your pillowcase once a week.¬† Is it best to air-dry or blow-dry your hair after washing? Ultimately, whether you blow-dry your hair, let it air-dry or sleep with it wet is entirely down to personal preference, but from a dermatologist‚Äôs point of view, it‚Äôs best to dry hair thoroughly before going to bed. ‚ÄúNot just for better scalp health,‚Äù says Dr. Wong, ‚Äúbut also because your hair is at its weakest when wet and therefore most prone to breakage in this state.‚Äù Proudman agrees: ‚ÄúWet hair can easily be broken, so I always advise to go to sleep with dry hair for both scalp and hair health.‚Äù Depending on your length and hair texture, Dr. Wong considers air-drying to be time-consuming, but it‚Äôs also impractical for a lot of people, especially if you wash your hair in the evening. She has a trick for mopping up water, though: ‚ÄúI would advise using a microfibre towel to dry the hair first, as this significantly increases water absorption and therefore [reduces] the time needed for any subsequent air-drying or heat drying.‚Äù Try Kitsch Extra Large Quick-Dry Hair Towel Wrap, $26, or the Act+Acre Microfiber Hair Towel, $30, if you have more to spend.¬† What‚Äôs the best hairdryer for no heat damage? If it‚Äôs heat damage that‚Äôs preventing you from blow-drying your hair, consider a smart blowdryer like the Shark SpeedStyle Pro FLEX 4-in-1 High-Velocity Hair Dryer System, $179.99. I also love the clever Dyson Supersonic Nural Hairdryer, $499, which uses sensors to tweak both airflow and temperature, minimizing the chance of burning your scalp and protecting hair strands in the process. If you‚Äôd rather spend less, try the BaBylissPRO Nano Titanium Compact Folding Ionic Dryer, $69.99, which boasts impressive airflow. And remember: Heat protectant spray exists for a reason.¬† Lastly, if you‚Äôre air-drying your hair, consider a targeted air-dry cream to reduce waiting time. Try JVN Complete Hydrating Air Dry Hair Styling Cream, $28, with smoothing squalane and moringa seed oil. Also try Briogeo Style + Treat Air Dry Hair Styling Cream, $26, with deeply moisturizing shea butter and glycerin, and Curlsmith Weightless Air Dry Cream, $27, with castor and jojoba oil, both of which are perfect for curly hair but can be used on all hair types. Like what you see? How about some more R29 goodness, right here?Black Hair Experts On The Dyson Airstrait BacklashHair Products Experts Won't Spend More Than $15 OnAre We Losing Our Black Hair Care Recipes?

title: 14 Nail Polish Gift Sets That Pros and Editors Recommend
description: It's time to get started on your holiday shopping. Figuring out where to begin can feel a little overwhelming, especially when searching for the perfect nail polish gift set. It seems like every year, people start their hunt earlier and earlier. While we're all for getting things crossed off our to-do lists in a timely manner, as soon as people shift into holiday gear, the good gifts have a tendency to sell out faster than you can say present. That's why it's always a good idea to get ahead of things. This year, there are new nail polish shades, tools, and Advent calendars to discover. This means there are pages and pages of scrolling to be done before you can finally find the perfect gifts for nail lovers. Fortunately for you, we've made it our mission to make your holiday shopping as easy as possible. We tapped some of our most trusted nail experts to weigh in on their top choices, so you know these picks are good. On top of that, we also polled all of our editors, and they clued us in on some pretty special picks. Whether you're looking for something simple like a starter set for a friend who is just getting into DIY manicures or something more involved like a Gel-X extension kit for a seasoned pro, there's an item for every manicure-obsessed person on your list. Ahead, keep scrolling to find the best nail polish gift sets and more. Experts Featured in This Article Mazz Hanna is the CEO of Nailing Hollywood, an agency for nail technicians based in Los Angeles. San Sung Kim is a Nailing Hollywood nail artist located in Los Angeles. Erica Hipp is a Nailing Hollywood nail artist located in Los Angeles. Related: These Editor-Approved Perfume Gift Sets Will Make Holiday Shopping a Breeze
author: Renee Rodriguez

title: See Florence Pugh's Tattoos, From a Bee to a Matchstick
description: Florence Pugh's tattoo collection is growing, and fast. The actor, who is a consistent source of inspiration for pretty much anything effortlessly cool - be it a bold new hair color or piercing placement idea - got her first tattoo back in 2019 and hasn't stopped since. In fact, in the course of the last few years, the "We Live in Time" star has amassed a total of four known tattoos. As for her style of choice? Pugh doesn't have one (unlike many celebrities who tend to stick to one aesthetic). Pugh has played around with different tattoo styles from fine line work to more intricate designs and even script, with some of her ink being more hidden than others. From her very first tattoo - which was a snail design that ended up becoming a bee, as one does - to her most recent "match stick" ink, we tracked down each one's special meaning and story. In the process, we ended up uncovering some funny facts about the "Midsommar" star that only added to the list of reasons to love her. Keep reading to get a closer look at Florence Pugh's four tattoos - we won't judge you if you zoom all the way in for a better look - and learn what each one means.
author: Ariel Baker
